sections.heading: Basic Concepts
content: Propositional Logic is the foundational system of formal logic dealing with propositions and their relationships.
The Law of Non-Contradiction states that a statement and its negation cannot both be true at the same time.
The Principle of Excluded Middle establishes that either a proposition or its negation must be true.
A logical inference is the process of deriving conclusions from premises through valid reasoning steps.
The method of Natural Deduction provides a systematic approach to constructing formal proofs.

sections.heading: Formal Systems
content: A formal system consists of an alphabet, formation rules, axioms, and inference rules.
The concept of Well-Formed Formula defines the syntactically correct expressions in a logical system.
An axiom schema is a pattern for generating specific axioms within a formal system.
The technique of Resolution provides a complete method for automated theorem proving.
The principle of Soundness ensures that only valid conclusions can be derived from true premises.

sections.heading: Semantics
content: The notion of Truth Value assigns a semantic interpretation to logical expressions.
A Truth Table provides a systematic method for evaluating compound propositions.
The concept of Validity determines whether an argument preserves truth from premises to conclusion.
The method of Semantic Tableaux offers an alternative approach to proving logical validity.
A Model Theory provides the mathematical framework for understanding logical semantics.
